questions.question: It the study of the interaction between people and computers.
Is is a multidisciplinary field that draws knowledge and methods from various discipline to understand and improve the interaction between humans and computers.
(1945)Vennevar Bush describes a ________, which is a precursor to hypertext.
(1962)Douglas Engelbert introduces this concept ________.
(1968)Ivan Sutherland develops ________, one of the first graphical user interfaces.
(1973)Xerox PARC develops the ________, which features a graphical user interface similar to the Macintosh.
(1984)The ________ is released, popularizing the use of graphical user interfaces.
(1993)The ________ is created, which makes it possible for people to interact with computer over the internet.
(2007)The ________ was released, which popularized the use of touchscreens.
(2011)The first commercial augmented reality(AR) headset was ________.
Refers to the ease with which a user can interact with a system or product to achieve their goals. A system or product is considered usable if it is intuitive, efficient, and user-friendly.

Encompasses the overall feelings, perceptions, and responses of a user when interacting with a product or system. It includes aspects like satisfaction, enjoyment, efficiency, and effectiveness of the interaction.

Concerned with making technology and digital content usable by individuals with disabilities. This includes ensuring that people with various impairments can perceive, understand, navigate, and interact with digital systems.

Ensuring that a system or product is free from errors, crashes, and security vulnerabilities. Users should feel confident that the technology will perform as expected without harming them or their data.
Refers to the system's ability to accomplish tasks quickly and with minimal effort on the part of the user. It involves how well a system or product performs its intended functions.
Refer to a system's ability to adapt to different user needs or changing circumstances. An adaptable and flexible system can be customized to suit different user preferences and requirements.

They involve addressing the ethical implications of technology use and its impact on society. This includes issues like data privacy, security, bias, and the broader societal implications of technology.

enumeration.question: Enumerate the Primary Goal of HCI

questions.question: Involves the study of human behavior, cognition, and emotions as they relate to the use of technology. Psychologists in HCI research areas like user behavior, perception, decision-making, and user motivation to inform design and user experience.

Provides the technical foundation for HCI. It encompasses the development of software, hardware, and systems that facilitate human-computer interaction. Computer scientists in HCI work on creating technology that is efficient, functional, and user-friendly.

Refers to the process of creating user interfaces and overall user experiences. Designers focus on the visual and interaction aspects of software and hardware to ensure that they are aesthetically pleasing and easy to use.
This field focuses on designing technology to fit human capabilities, limitations, and comforts.

Concerned with the study of human cognition, including memory, attention, problem-solving, and decision-making. HCI researchers draw from cognitive science to understand how users process information and make decisions when interacting with technology.
Involves the management and organization of information, data, and knowledge. In HCI, it's important for designing systems that present information in a structured and understandable manner.

Brings a cultural and social perspective to HCI. Researchers in these fields study how technology is adopted and used in different cultural and social contexts, considering factors like values, norms, and societal impact.

Understanding how language and communication play a role in user interfaces, voice recognition, and natural language processing. It helps in designing interfaces that effectively interpret and generate human language.

Is a research method used in HCI to observe and understand how people use technology in their natural environments. It involves immersive field studies to gain insights into user behaviors, needs, and contexts.

enumeration.question: Enumerate the Disciplines Contributing to HCI

questions.question: Involves creating interfaces and systems that are intuitive, easy to use, and enjoyable for users. It focuses on designing with the user's needs and preferences in mind, minimizing the learning curve, and providing a positive user experience.
It involves designing interfaces that prevent users from making mistakes, providing clear feedback, and guiding users to achieve their goals without undue frustration.

Refers to designing computer systems and interfaces that align with the way users naturally work and interact in their everyday lives. It aims to make technology relevant and practical, ensuring that users can easily integrate it into their existing routines and tasks.

Integrating HCI considerations into the design process means involving HCI experts and usability testing throughout the development cycle. This ensures that usability and user experience factors are considered from the initial design stages and continue to be addressed throughout the development process.

Dealing with sensitive data or applications that may pose risks to users. It involves adhering to regulations, standards, and guidelines to protect user data, ensure product safety, and meet legal obligations in various domains.
The one whom computer system are designed to assist. THe Requirements of the user should therefore be our first priority.
Is a model of human information processing.

Information from sensory memory is transferred to short-term memory through.

Information from short-term memory can be transfered to long-term memory through.

It involves the storage of factual knowledge, concepts, and information that are not tied to specific personal experiences. This type of memory encompasses a wide range of information, such as facts, concepts, language, and general knowledge about the world.
Also known as Working Memory.

enumeration.question: The three main components of the user as an information processing system.

questions.question: Head (Output to Input)
Eyes (Output to Input)
Facial Muscles (Output to Input)
Vocal Apparatus (Output to Input)
Hands and Fingers (Output to Input)
Feet and Legs (Output to Input)
This component represents how humans gather information from the environment. It involves sensory processes such as vision, hearing, touch, and other senses.
It is responsible for executing physical actions in response to the information processed by the cognitive system.

It is responsible for tasks such as memory, attention, problem-solving, decision-making, and language processing. It processes the information received from the perceptual system and generates actions based on that information.
refers to the sensory memory associated with visual information. It is extremely short-lived, lasting only for a fraction of a second (typically less than a second).
the sensory memory associated with auditory information, such as sounds and spoken language. It lasts longer than iconic memory, typically around 2 to 4 seconds
This sensory information helps you recognize objects, navigate your environment, and perform various tactile tasks.
Using knowledge to draw conclusion or infer new information.
Derives a logically necessary conclusion from given premises, even if it doesn't always align with our notion of truth.
Generalized from observed cases to infer information about unobserved cases, although it may not be entirely reilable.
Reasons from a fact to the cause of the fact, helping us derive explanations for observed events.
It is process of finding a solution to an unfamiliar task using the knowledge we have.
In this theory, you are deviding or restructuring the problem and gaining insight to find innovattive solutions.
We called it a trial and error theory.
Refers to the process of gaining experties and proficiency in a particular domain over time. It is a complex process that involves a number of factors.
It is a factor in skill acquisition that said, you are gaining skill through teaching

Refers to the repetitive and purposeful engagement in a specific task or activity to improve one's skills and proficiency. In HCI, this can involve practicing user interface design, interaction techniques, or other aspects of human-computer interaction.

involves receiving information about the quality and effectiveness of one's actions or interactions with a computer system. This information can be in the form of user testing results, usability evaluations, or direct user feedback.

Refers to the theoretical understanding and knowledge of principles, concepts, and models that underlie HCI. This knowledge can include human cognition, user experience (UX) design principles, information architecture, and various HCI models.
Refers to the awareness and understanding of one's cognitive processes, including the ability to monitor, control, and optimize one's learning and problem-solving strategies.
Are unintentional actions that devirate from the desired outcome. They can range from minor inconveniences to serious consequences.

This model is widely used in the field of Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) and user experience (UX) design to understand how users interact with systems and how design can influence the user experience.
This model emphasizes that the user experience goes beyond usability and functionality, considering the emotional and hedonic aspects of user interactions.

enumeration.question: Kinds of Interaction and User Experience

questions.question: A step-by-step approach followed to create user-centered experience and prototypes, from unnderstanding user needs to evaluating the final design.
A well-defined process provides a clear path for designing and evaluating user interfaces, ensuring that all relevant aspects are considered.
A process helps in systematically identifying user needs, conducting research, prototyping, testing, and iterating, leading to more effective HCI solutions.
Following a consistent process promotes reliability in design outcomes, making it easier to replicate successful designs and avoid errors.
A process can serve as a framework for both newcomers and experienced professionals, helping them understand and teach HCI principles and methods.
Having a standardized process fosters a common understanding among team members, facilitating collaboration and communication in HCI projects.
It is cycle that emcompasses the process of designing a user experience, starting from ideation to deployment and beyond.
It is a depiction of how the activities of the lifecycle are organized and arrange in chronological.
It is a structured framework that guides the process of designing a user experience.
These are the essential tasks and steps that are performed during the process of creating a user experience.
These are the different approaches used to carry out the main activities or subactivities in the user experience design process.
These are specific, detailed practices used to perform individual steps within the activities, subactivities, or methods of the user experience design process.
Specific tasks and actions performed within each main activity if the user experience design process.

enumeration.question: The Basic Process Components for UX

questions.question: Involves keenly and objectively watching people, events, or situations to gather information and insights.
Is the process of simplifying complex information or concepts into more manageable and understandable forms.
Involves recording important information, ideas, or observations for future reference or organization.
Is the skill of structuring and categorizing information logically and efficiently.
entails creating representations or visualizations of objects, systems, or processes to understand them better.
is the art of conveying information, ideas, or experiences through narratives that engage and captivate an audience.
involves fully engaging in an experience or environment to gain a deep understanding of it.
is a creative technique for generating a wide range of ideas and solutions within a group.
involve visually representing ideas, concepts, or designs through hand-drawn images.
is the way in which a problem or situation is presented, and involves looking at it from different perspectives.
is the ability to form logical conclusions, and involves drawing specific conclusions from general information.
is the creation of preliminary models or representations of a design or idea, and involves imagining future scenarios.
involves analyzing and evaluating information or arguments.
Refers to the process of refining and improving a design through multiple cycles or rounds of evaluation, feedback, and revision.

enumeration.question: UX Design Techniques as Life Skills

questions.question: This activity involves gaining insights into users, their work practices, usage patterns, and the subject-matter domain to understand their needs and requirements for the design.
In this activity, designer create designs as solutions to address the identified user needs and challenges.
Designers build prototypes of promising design solutions to visualize and test their effectiveness.
This activity involves verifying and refining the designs based on user feedback and insight to ensure a positive user experience.
This involves interviewing and observing users while they work to gather data about their practices, preference, and needs.
The collected usage research data is distilled and organized for better comprehension.
Representation are created to capture user characteristics, information, flow, tasks, and work environments. These model aid collaboration, sharing, archival, rehearsal, and immension.
This subacitivity invloves codifying the needs and requirements identified during the reseach process.
In This sub-activity, designers engage in ideation and sketching to create various design ideas.
This sub-activity involves creating mental models, system models, and storyboards to flesh out the design concepts.
This sub-activity focuses on specifying detailed plans for implementing the selected design.
In this place, desingers develop ecological, interaction, and emotional design plans for the most promising candidates.
DEsigners develop hand-drawn or printed paper prototypes to explore and visualize design concepts in low fidelity.
Designers create basic visual representations of the user interface and interaction flow.
Desingers create interactive prototypes that allow users to navigate through the design with clickable elements, providing a more dynamic representation of the user experience.
For physical products or tangible interactions, designers create physical prototyes to test and evaluate the designs functionality and usability.

Desingers use various methods, such as user testing, surveys, or analysis, to gather data on how users interact with the design. This data provides valuable insights into user behavior and preferences.
The collected daya is analyzed to identify patterns, official incidents, and root causes. This analysis helps designers understand the strengths and weakness of the design.
Based on the evaluation results, designers propose changes and improvements to address identified issues and enhance the user experience.

The evaluation findings and proposed redesign solution solution are documented and communicated to stakeholders and the design team. This ensures everyone knows the evaluation outcomes and the design team. This ensures everyone knows the evaluation outcomes and the next steps for refining the design.

Quantifies the amount of time taken by an algorithm to run as a function of the length of the input.

Amount of time spent in executing instructions of a given akgorithm. Notation: T(n). Several factors: input size, instruction type, machine speed, quality of source of the algorithm implementation, quality of the machine code generated from the source code by the computer.
Quantifies the amount of space or memory taken by an algorithm to run as a function of the lenght of the input.

A method of analyzing an algorithm by determining: the number of times eacch program line runs, time required to execute each line, no. of times each procedures were called, total space alocated to run the program, etc.
The analysis solely on the way algorithms solve problems.
What the designer can control.
